docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Uncertain Election Plan In Peru Concerns U.S. The sudden decision by Peru's president, Alberto K. Fujimori, to call new elections and not run in them himself took the United States and all of Latin America by surprise, officials said. While welcoming the move, they expressed concern that Peru might face a period of unrest and voiced uncertainty about what role its army might play. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of Medicare patients receiving hospice care more than doubled in the last decade, but they are not getting the full value of the services because they often sign up for hospice benefits just a few days or weeks before they die, federal investigators said today. In a new report, the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said that 28 percent of all Medicare beneficiaries in the hospice program received hospice care for one week or less.

headline.main: More Patients in Hospice Care, But for Far Fewer Final Days

docs.abstract: New General Accounting Office report finds number of Medicare patients receiving hospice care more than doubled in last decade, but that they are not getting full value of services because they often sign up for hospice benefits just few days or weeks before they die; findings discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eddie Williams, 30 years old, counts himself lucky to have a good job, making $17 an hour as a deliveryman for the Bowman Oil and Propane Company. He and his wife are careful about their budget, and so have been able to sock away some savings for their daughter, Tianna, 6, and their son, Kendan, 4. They were able to vacation in Southern California this summer and visit relatives in Nevada. But all their planning got a jolt a few weeks ago, when health insurance premiums for the two children abruptly shot up by 40 percent -- to $350 a month from $250.

headline.main: Frustration Grows With Cost of Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Millions of Americans are grappling with soaring expense of health insurance premiums, some rising by 10 percent and more, even as consumer prices fell in past month for first time in 14 years; wonder why increases are so large and express puzzlement and anger at economic forces driving them; say larger premiums, which insurers say are caused by rising cost of prescription drugs, and more generally by escalating demands for medical services, are playing havoc with their budgets; effects of increases on workers, managers and owner of Bowman Oil and Propane, small company in Tacoma, Wash, discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The presidential candidates and the voters are now happily engaged in an orgy of self-congratulation for finally touching the third rail of American politics, Social Security and Medicare. We are told that we are confronting the hard choices that others less courageous have been unwilling to make. The melancholy truth is that what poses for debate on entitlements may be worse than no debate at all. The bidding and one-upmanship on the campaign trail could easily lock the new president into indefensible positions that block genuine and badly needed reforms.
docs.abstract: Peter G Peterson's Op-Ed article on proposals by presidential candidates to reform Social Security and Medicare; says, contrary to assertions that we are facing hard choices that others less courageous have been unwilling to make, truth is that what poses for debate on entitlements may be worse than no debate at all; says bidding and one-upmanship on campaign trail could easily lock new president into indefensible positions that block genuine and badly needed reforms; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Did I miss something in my reading of the article? Should the title have been ''Who Wants to Be the Cheapest?'' You write that Mary Barknecht ''lives on $11,000 a year, most of which goes for rent and health insurance.'' Why bother with the health insurance? Doesn't Medicaid cover you at this level? ''Her other expenses total about $100 a month.'' Is this a typo? Does she eat? What does she eat? Does she wash her clothes? Have a telephone? Electric lights? Maybe she should write a book, but I guess that would be too complicated.

headline.main: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'

docs.abstract: Janet Bidwell letter on September 3 article holds simplifying one's life is much too complicated (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A headline asks, ''What if There Is No Cure for Health Care's Ills?'' (Week in Review, Sept. 10). But the obvious solution is the approach that almost every other industrialized country has used to attain universal coverage: single-payer national health insurance.
docs.abstract: Dr Bob LeBow letter on Sept 10 article on high cost of medical care and providing health insurance for everyone; suggests single-payer national health insurance--in effect, Medicare for all--as way to bring affordable health care to every American

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have made clear the differences in how they would use the federal budget surplus, the much-anticipated but as yet unrealized bounty of prosperity. But both candidates face the same question: Can the government really afford what they are proposing?

headline.main: Candidates' Budget Numbers Rely on Optimistic Outlook

docs.abstract: Close reading of Vice Pres Al Gore's and Gov George W Bush's budget proposals and interviews with economists and analysts inside and outside campaigns suggest proposals are more substantive than those developed by two parties in previous elections, but hinge on optimistic assumptions; proposals provide look at candidates' priorities and test of their fiscal responsibility; Gore has built more of buffer into his budget; Bush has less wiggle room, even by own reckoning, should surplus fall short of expectations or need for new spending be greater than he assumes; Bush stresses tax cut, Gore new spending and debt reduction; table of proposals; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Running for office as a Socialist is the ultimate exercise in egalitarianism, so Greg Pason, the Socialist Party USA's candidate for U. S. Senate seat from New Jersey, has no complaints about shuttling around the campaign trail aboard New Jersey Transit trains. Mr. Pason doesn't bemoan the fact that his job as the party's national secretary pays $12 an hour (the same figure as the party's proposed minimum wage) or that his budget for the primary was a paltry $1,370.

headline.main: $400 Million Man a Socialist? Don't Tell That to a Socialist

docs.abstract: David Kocieniewski On Politics column on Socialist Party candidate for Senate in New Jersey, Greg Pason, and his reaction to Jon Corzine, former Wall Street chief executive worth $400 million and Democratic candidate for US Senate seat from New Jersey, who is viewed by many voters as socialist (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Greyhound seems to carry more people away from here than it ever brings back. Cindy Lamb works the cash register at the bus stop, and, one ticket stub at a time, she sells young people a way out of Dixie County. ''There's nothing for them here but the logging in the woods, or at a sawmill,'' she said, making change at the Chevron station that also serves as the bus depot. Her own son left to find work in the Georgia carpet mills.

headline.main: In a Working-Poor Town, Candidates Are Dismissed as Being Out of Touch

docs.lead_paragraph: Robin Lynn Segal, the daughter of Dr. Joy Segal and Michael Segal of Chicago, was married on Friday to John David Edelman, a son of Ruth and Daniel Edelman, also of Chicago. Judge Anne Burke of the Illinois Appellate Court in Chicago, officiated at the Jens Jensen Preserve, a landmark and a home of the bride's parents in Ravinia, Ill. The bride, 33, is keeping her name. She is of counsel to the Near North National Group, an insurance brokerage firm in Chicago of which her father is the owner and chairman. Her mother is a private and corporate consultant on work and family issues in Chicago.
